Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 05:36PM Jdx0424 wrote: You all are the best!  thank you for posting.  i looked forward to getting home tonight to see what was out here.  i'm not sure that i have clarity yet, but you gave me some good "food for thought" and some that it's difficult to get from your family and friends who aren't "experienced" with BC.  I know, they are doing their best! This past week with having the four biopsies done at once---i was at the imaging center for six hours and then finding out that they still want another with the MRI machine, i was (am) feeling really down about 1) going through all of this only to end up doing the mastectomy and 2) having to do this again in a few years when the next suspicious area is found.  It feels a bit like a game of "duck, duck, goose".........only "benign, benign, cancer"!  However, the alternative surgical option.....well, it sucks.  Please tell me that once i finally am able to make a decision and move forward that I will stop crying!  I feel like i am already in mourning and i haven't lost anything yet.  Thanks for a place to vent.  I really do appreciate all of your input.  Stay tuned.
Posts.Title: Conflicted--L vs M? Hardest decision ever! Jdx0424 Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Jdx0424 wrote: I am having such a difficult time deciding which direction to go.  The BC has ordered a MR biopsy to make sure that he can get good margins and a lumpectomy is an option--this is after a plethora of other tests, BUT even if it is, in the 8 years prior to the diagnosis of actual CANCER, I have had 4 biopsies.  I don't think I've every had a clean mammagram for more than a year or so.  This time I've had four biopsies done--1 surgical because it's close to the surface (the one i found and is cancer), 3 US guided needle biopsies (the ones the mammo and US found--1 of those is cancer), and now they want to do the MR biopsy.  I am wondering if saving the beloved ta-ta's is worth repeating this process again.   I know i've read tons of postings from those that are happy with their choice of mastectomy, but i can't help but be devastated at the thought of replacing the pair that have served me well with a pair that look and feel like they aren't really a part of me.  I read an article by Christina Applegate recently were she referred to it as an amputation and that she was not prepared for the emotional issues afterwards.  I didn't know until this article that she actually had a lumpectomy first, got her BRAC analysis and then had the mastectomy.  Her comments resonated with me.......  Anyway.....just curious if anyone else has had this same struggle.  I am usually a very definitive person and the time it's taking to get all the diagnostics done plus mulling over both options is such a downer!  I don't do sad well!
